Abstract. In his fundamental work on the stack
genus g curves, Finn F. Knudsen introduced the concept of a stably reexive
module in order to prove a key technical lemma. We propose an alternative
denition and generalise the results in his appendix to [21]. Then we give a
coordinate free generalisation of his lemma, generalise a construction used
in Knudsens proof concerning versal families of pointed algebras, and show
that Knudsens stabilisation construction works for plane curve singularities.
In addition we prove approximation theorems generalising Cohen-Macaulay
approximation with stably reexive modules in at families. The generalisation
is not covered (even in the closed bres) by the Auslander-Buchweitz axioms.
1. Introduction
In order to establish the stabilisation map from the universal curve Cg,n to the
Mg,n+1 Knudsen developed in [21] a theory of what he called stably reexive
stack
modules with respect to a at ring homomorphism. In this article we take a closer
look at this theory and some of its applications both in approximation theory of
modules and in deformation theory.
We reformulate Knudsens theory by rst dening an absolute notion of a stably
reexive module over a ring. In the noetherian case this is the same as a module of
Gorenstein dimension 0. Then we dene a stably reexive module with respect to a
at ring homomorphism as a at family of stably reexive modules. By cohomology-
and-base-change theory this denition is equivalent to Knudsens.
We introduce a descending series of additive categories of modules, called n-
stably reexive modules. For n = 1 these are the reexive modules. The stably
reexive modules are n-stably reexive for all n. We also dene an absolute and
a relative notion of n-stably reexive complexes. An n-stably reexive complex
(E, d) gives an n-stably reexive module coker d1. In the noetherian case the
stably reexive complexes are Tate resolutions relative to a base ring. Finally, there
is a third concept of a at family of n-orthogonal modules dened by a one-sided
cohomology condition. An 2n-orthogonal module determines and is determined by
an n-stably reexive module through the (n+1)-syzygy. Together Propositions 3.5,
4.3 and 4.6 extend Theorem 2 in [21, Appendix]; see Remark 4.8.
